name: 9H-Xanthen-9-ol
Reason: The compound 9H-Xanthen-9-ol is composed of a tricyclic fused system similar to xanthene with a hydroxyl group. The xanthene core has a molecular structure resembling naphthalene with an additional bridging carbon atom. For comparison, naphthalene has a melting point of around 80. Since 9H-Xanthen-9-ol has a more complex polycyclic structure compared to naphthalene, this will considerably increase its melting point due to greater π-π stacking and van der Waals forces. The addition of the hydroxyl group contributes to an increase in melting point through the capability of forming hydrogen bonds. However, the effect of the hydroxyl group is somewhat less as compared to the larger polyaromatic hydrocarbon structure. Therefore, the combining effect of the polyaromatic structure and the hydroxyl group will yield a melting point significantly higher than naphthalene's, but quantitatively it's difficult to precisely predict the melting point change due to the complexity of the structure.
Test (Predicted reason):
The compound 9H-Xanthen-9-ol has several functional groups that influence its melting point. The basic structure is a xanthene, which has a melting point of around 100°C. The presence of a hydroxyl group (OH) typically increases the melting point due to hydrogen bonding; this effect could be estimated at +20. The ketone (C=O) group also contributes to the melting point through dipole-dipole interactions; this could be estimated at +15. The compound has two phenyl rings, which would increase the melting point due to pi-pi interactions and increased molecular rigidity; each ring could add +20. The presence of a methyl group (CH3) might slightly lower the melting point due to its small size and flexibility; this effect could be estimated at -5.
